a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 31"
and h1 : "k = 28"
shows  "binomial n k = 4495"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{31}{28}$. The final Answer is 4495
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{31}{28} &= \dbinom{31}{3} \\ &= \dfrac{31!}{28!3!} \\ &= \dfrac{31\times 30\times 29}{3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 31 \times \dfrac{30}{3\times 2\times 1} \times 29 \\ &= 31\times 5\times 29 \\
 &= \boxed{4495}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 31"
and h1 : "k = 28"
shows  "binomial n k = 4495"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the binomial coefficient of $n = 31$ and $k = 28$. The final answer is 4495.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: nat and binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial = (\<lambda> n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binomial 31 28 = 4495"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{31}{28}$. The final Answer is 4495
 ### Proof
 \begin{align} \dbinom{31}{28} &= \dbinom{31}{3} \\ &= \dfrac{31!}{28!3!} \\ &= \dfrac{31\times 30\times 29}{3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 31 \times \dfrac{30}{3\times 2\times 1} \times 29 \\ &= 31\times 5\times 29 \\
 &= \boxed{4495}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: nat and binomial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "binomial = (\<lambda> n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "binomial 31 28 = 4495"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the binomial coefficient of $C_{31}^{28}$ using the formula $C(n,k)=\frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$. The final answer is 4495.
